awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Seismic attenuation and anelasticity in the upper mantle: the effect of continuous far-field dislocation creep
awd_abstract_narration:
Thermal convection in the Earth's mantle drives plate tectonics, at the origin of numerous hazards such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. The upper mantle, which lies beneath the crust to depths of 410 km, is largely unreachable.  Seismology is, thus, a major tool when investigating mantle features.  Seismic-wave energy can be absorbed by the materials through which they pass, a process called seismic attenuation. This allows to identify structures at depth like the presence of melt. Each attenuation process must first be characterized in the laboratory.  Wave amplitude can be attenuated by back-and-forth motions of dislocations, which are linear defects shearing minerals during deformation. Here, the team measures experimentally the effects of rocks' microstructure, such as dislocations and grain orientations, on the attenuation of seismic waves.  The researchers use water ice as analog for mantle rocks because ice physical properties are well known. Ice can also be deformed to high strain at modest pressure and stress conditions. During deformation, ice specimens are here exposed to low-amplitude oscillating stress like those induced by seismic waves, while the attenuation is quantified. Results from this research provide critical insights to understand glaciers' and ice-sheet behavior and the role of rocks microstructures on seismic attenuation. The project has direct implications in Seismology and broader impacts in Material Sciences and Planetary Science (icy planetary bodies). It also provides support for an early-career female scientist, training for a post-doctoral associate in the field of Rocks Physics and outreach to high-school students.

The team expands on their previous studies of ice behavior by exploring seismic-wave attenuation as a function of strain in polycrystalline ice. The study is designed to explore upper mantle conditions in terms of microstructure: dislocation density,  sub-grain size and crystal preferred orientation. The goal is to measure the attenuation signature for materials experiencing a high background stress in the dislocation creep regime. Preliminary laboratory studies have identified an increase in attenuation in highly strained samples. Yet, the controlling parameters and the nature of how dislocation damping scales to the mantle is not known. Here, samples are pre-deformed to high strain in either shear torsion or compression in the high-pressure cryogenic deformation apparatus at University of Pennsylvania. Their microstructure is characterized by light microscopy and back scatter diffraction in a cryo-scanning electron microscope. Specimens are then tested for attenuation over a broad frequency range in the ambient-pressure cryogenic apparatus at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (Columbia University). The results are used to estimate the effect of both mantle stress magnitude and fabric strength on seismic attenuation. They will also have applications to glaciers and ice sheets on Earth and icy planetary bodies experiencing tidal forcing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When an earthquake occurs, seismic energy is radiated in every direction. These seismic waves are damped and polarized when they pass through the Earth, resulting in seismic attenuation and anisotropy, respectively. Our understanding of the microphysical processes causing attenuation and polarization are key to our ability to interpret seismic data to identify conditions prevailing in the Earth’s upper mantle (e.g., grain-size, melt fraction, temperature, water content, and mantle flow patterns). It is widely agreed that the upper mantle deforms through a dislocation creep mechanism, which manifests itself through shearing of crystals to create dislocations and eventual alignment of crystals into a fabric or crystallographic preferred orientation (CPO). However, the effects of dislocation damping and CPO on attenuation have been largely overlooked. The proposed research was designed to simulate upper mantle conditions in terms of microstructure, dislocation–density, and texture, and measure their effects on attenuation. To accomplish this the study used polycrystalline ice as an analogue material. Ice is an excellent analogue for upper mantle rock because conditions of high homologous temperature that are difficult for mantle materials, are relatively easy to obtain with ice. Additionally, the conditions needed to deform by dislocation creep are readily accessible in the lab. In order to accomplish the research, a cryogenic uniaxial testing apparatus was designed and built. This high-precision, high-resolution ice attenuation apparatus includes numerous features which allow it to very accurately apply and measure small stresses and strains: dual laser displacement meters and a rotating stage that allows the user to accurately center the load point; a trio of load cells that also provides centering information; and a piezo-electric actuator that applies small amplitude oscillations at desired frequencies. Cryogenic temperature control was additionally included and a large load cell working range so that dislocation density can be maintained during cyclic loading tests. The study is measuring the attenuation of polycrystalline ice samples that have been systematically pre-deformed under confinement in the apparatus at U. Penn. The results of the proposed study will estimate the effect of both the mantle stress magnitude (through dislocation-density) and mantle accommodated strain (through the CPO) with the observations of attenuation. In addition, the connection between strain induced CPO and stress induced dislocation-density will be a starting point for future relations between observations of seismic attenuation and seismic anisotropy studies.  

The work supported a PI, a postdoc, and several undergraduates involved through Columbia’s work study and REU programs. Additionally, both PI and postdoc provided a significant amount of outreach and education, which exposed pre-school, elementary, and high school aged students from a variety of socioeconomic backgrounds to hands on, glacier and earthquake related activities and research.
